content: The list provides names of independent counsels appointed by the special Division of the Court for Appointing Independent Counsels, United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia. It summarizes areas of investigation, results, and costs derived from audits by the Government Accountability Office or Senate Committee on Governmental Affairs reports. The list of independent counsels and special prosecutors appointed by the Special Division of the Court includes those whose identities and investigative jurisdictions have been kept confidential. Information on appointments and investigation targets was generally confidential under former federal law unless deemed in the public interest to release. The total costs of 20 independent counsel investigations initiated under the Ethics in Government Act of 1978 amounted to approximately $228,712,589 by September 30, 2005. The statutory provisions for independent counsels expired in 1999, preventing new appointments. The Attorney General can appoint temporary personnel within the Department of Justice for investigations and prosecutions. Regulations for special counsels were established in 1999. Previous special counsel investigations have incurred significant costs, such as Robert Fiske's Whitewater investigation costing $6,073,000. Former Senator John Danforth's special counsel investigation of the Waco incident has cost $15,536,793. The Justice Department appointed Patrick Fitzgerald as a Special Counsel to investigate the unauthorized disclosure of a CIA employee's identity, with expenses totaling $902,118 as of September 31, 2005. The total expenses of the special counsel investigation into the unauthorized disclosure of a CIA employee's identity were $902,118 as of September 31, 2005. Out of 20 independent counsel investigations, 12 did not result in any indictments. In 8 investigations that did lead to indictments, 3 cases did not result in indictments against the principal government official initially targeted. In 5 investigations where the official was indicted, 3 were acquitted or had their convictions overturned. Out of 20 independent counsel investigations, only two federal officials who were the named subjects were convicted or pleaded guilty. In one case, a presidential aide was convicted of perjury, while in another case, a Secretary pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor charge and was eventually pardoned by the President. The special prosecutors and independent counsels appointed under federal law investigated allegations of cocaine use by President Carter's Chief of Staff and national campaign manager. The investigations found insufficient evidence for criminal charges and were closed. Leon Silverman investigated allegations against President Reagan's Secretary of Labor Raymond J. Donovan, finding insufficient evidence for prosecution. The investigation cost $318,000. A further investigation in 1985 regarding false testimony before a grand jury resulted in no indictments sought, costing $7,200. Independent counsel Alexia Morrison was appointed to investigate allegations against former Assistant Attorney General Theodore B. Olson for giving false testimony to Congress regarding the EPA "superfund" inquiry. The investigation found insufficient credible evidence of false statements or obstruction of justice, and any prosecution based on congressional testimony would face legal obstacles. Independent counsel Alexia Morrison investigated allegations against former Assistant Attorney General Theodore B. Olson for false testimony to Congress regarding the EPA "superfund" inquiry. The investigation found no evidence of a conspiracy to obstruct a congressional committee's inquiry. Whitney North Seymour Jr. investigated charges against former President Reagan aide Michael K. Deaver for post-employment conflict of interest violations. Deaver was convicted of perjury and sentenced to probation and a fine. Lawrence E. Walsh was appointed to investigate potential criminal misconduct of Lt. Colonel Oliver North. Lt. Colonel Oliver North and other government officials were investigated for potential criminal misconduct in the Iran-Contra matter. Several individuals pleaded guilty or were convicted of federal offenses related to the scandal. Lt. Col. Oliver L. North and Rear Admiral John M. Poindexter, both government officials involved in the Iran-Contra scandal, were convicted of federal offenses. North had one conviction overturned and two dropped after his immunized congressional testimony was deemed tainted. Poindexter had five convictions overturned for the same reason. Other individuals indicted included Duane Clarridge and Joseph F. Fernandez. President George Bush pardoned several individuals involved in the Iran-Contra scandal, including Casper Weinberger, Duane Clarridge, Clair George, Elliott Abrams, Alan Fiers, and Robert McFarlane. The Independent Counsel's final report was filed in August 1993, with the investigation costing $47,873,400. James C. McKay was appointed to investigate allegations related to conflicts of interest involving former White House staffer Franklyn C. Nofziger. The Independent Counsel investigated post-employment conflicts of interest and lobbying activities related to Wedtech Corporation, including Attorney General Edwin Meese's conduct. The report concluded that while some of Meese's actions may have violated criminal laws, no prosecution was warranted. Insufficient evidence was found regarding bribery and illegal gratuities involving the Aqaba Pipeline. The Independent Counsel investigated various cases, including the conviction of Nofziger which was later overturned on technical grounds. Other investigations involved James R. Harper and Larry D. Thompson, with costs ranging from $50,000 to $2,796,000. No indictments were sought in some cases, and the investigations did not result in any prosecutions. The Independent Counsel investigated allegations of criminal conspiracy involving favoritism and payments to officials in the Department of Housing and Urban Development during the Reagan Administration. Former Secretary Samuel R. Pierce was not indicted due to admissions of mismanagement and corruption, age, health, lack of personal benefit, and conflicting evidence of intent. Carlos A. Figueroa pleaded guilty to making false statements. Several individuals, including Figueroa, Straus, Queenan, Mahon, and Villalpando, were involved in various criminal activities related to HUD grants and subsidies during the Reagan Administration. Figueroa pleaded guilty to making false statements, Straus pleaded guilty to conspiracy and cover-up, Queenan and Mahon were found guilty of bribery and conspiracy, and Villalpando pleaded guilty to obstruction of justice. Deborah Gore Dean, Thomas Demery, Robert B. Olsen, and Philip D. Winn were all involved in illegal activities related to HUD grants. Dean was found guilty of conspiracy, receipt of illegal gratuities, and perjury, while Demery pleaded guilty to accepting illegal gratuities and obstruction of justice. Olsen pleaded guilty to conspiracy and bribery, and Winn pleaded guilty to conspiracy charges for providing things of value to HUD officials. Several individuals, including Leonard Briscoe, Maurice Steier, and Lance H. Wilson, were convicted of giving illegal gratuities to HUD officials. Elaine Richardson pleaded guilty to aiding false statements to HUD, while Silvio J. DeBartolomeis pleaded guilty to conspiracy and accepting illegal income. Benton Mortgage Company also pleaded guilty to concealing material facts related to HUD payments. Several individuals, including Leonard Briscoe, Maurice Steier, and Lance H. Wilson, were convicted of giving illegal gratuities to HUD officials. Elaine Richardson pleaded guilty to aiding false statements to HUD, while Silvio J. DeBartolomeis pleaded guilty to conspiracy and accepting illegal income. Additionally, James G. Watt, former Secretary of the Interior, pleaded guilty to attempting to influence a federal Grand Jury. Victor R. Cruse, a former Connecticut housing official, was indicted for perjury and obstruction of justice but was acquitted. Philip D. Winn, former HUD Assistant Secretary for Housing, who pleaded guilty to conspiracy charges, was later pardoned by President Clinton. The independent counsel's final report was released in 1998, with the investigation costing over $29 million. The investigation led by Independent Counsel Michael F. Zeldin found no evidence of criminal wrongdoing in the search of Bill Clinton's passport files during the 1992 presidential campaign. The investigation cost $93,000 and concluded in November 1995. Julie F. Thomas succeeded Robert W. Ray as Independent Counsel in the Whitewater investigation, which began with allegations related to President Clinton and the First Lady's dealings with Madison Guarantee Savings and Loan Association. Independent Counsel Kenneth W. Starr was appointed in 1994 to continue the investigation, with his jurisdiction expanded in 1996 at the request of Attorney General Reno. The Independent Counsel investigation, initiated in 1994, was expanded multiple times to look into various allegations involving the White House staff, including the misuse of FBI files and false statements made before the House Committee. The investigation also delved into allegations of subornation of perjury, obstruction of justice, or intimidation of witnesses in the civil case involving President Clinton and Monica Lewinsky. Several individuals involved in the investigation have pleaded guilty to various charges. The Independent Counsel investigation, initiated in 1994, expanded to look into various allegations involving the White House staff. Pleas and convictions of several individuals, including former Arkansas Governor Jim Guy Tucker, were obtained. Additional indictments were reinstated by the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. The Independent Counsel investigation obtained a 15-count indictment against Webster Hubbell for concealment and false statements about land deals in Arkansas in the 1980s. Hubbell pleaded guilty to tax evasion and false statements charges. Other results included acquittals and hung juries for various individuals involved in the investigation. The trial of Julie Hyatt Steele for perjury and obstruction of justice in the Monica Lewinsky investigation ended in a mistrial. Independent Counsel Starr announced that Steele and Susan McDougal would not be retried on hung-jury counts. The "Whitewater aspect" of the Clintons' investigation was concluded, with no indictments of the President or First Lady expected. Independent Counsel Ray confirmed the insufficiency of evidence in a statement issued in September 2000. Independent Counsel Ray found insufficient evidence to prove beyond a reasonable doubt that President or Mrs. Clinton knowingly participated in criminal conduct related to Madison Guarantee, CMS, or Whitewater Development. Reports issued to the Special Division of the Court in March 2000 cleared White House officials, including Hillary Rodham Clinton, of engaging in criminal conduct or providing false testimony. Independent Counsel Ray found no credible evidence of false testimony by Mr. Nussbaum. On January 19, 2001, it was announced that Independent Counsel Ray would not prosecute President Clinton in the Monica Lewinsky and Paula Jones-deposition matter. President Clinton acknowledged and apologized for his conduct in the Paula Jones deposition, agreeing to a five-year suspension of his law license and a $25,000 fine. He pardoned four individuals involved in the Arkansas "Whitewater" investigation. Independent Counsel Starr reaffirmed findings on Vincent Foster's death and submitted a report in July 1997. The Independent Counsel investigated potential criminal conduct related to gifts received by Secretary of Agriculture Mike Espy. The investigation cost over $73 million, with additional expenses incurred by previous investigations. The Independent Counsel investigated potential criminal conduct related to gifts received by Secretary of Agriculture Mike Espy from companies regulated by the Department of Agriculture. Results included guilty pleas, fines, and settlements from various individuals and organizations. The Independent Counsel investigated potential criminal conduct related to gifts received by Secretary of Agriculture Mike Espy from companies regulated by the Department of Agriculture. This resulted in guilty pleas, fines, and settlements from various individuals and organizations, including Power Corp. of Georgia, Robert Mondavi Corporation, Tysons Foods, Inc., Sun-Diamond Growers of California, John Hemmingson, Alverez Ferrouillet Jr., and Ronald H. Blackley. Several individuals and organizations were involved in providing gifts and payments to Secretary Mike Espy at the Department of Agriculture, leading to convictions and guilty pleas. This included individuals like Richard Douglas, Jack L. Williams, and Archibald R. Schaffer, who were found guilty of false statements and providing gratuities to Secretary Espy. The court reinstated charges against individuals involved in providing gifts to Secretary Espy, including John J. Hemmingson, Gary Black, Henry Espy Jr., and Norris Faust Jr. Former Secretary Mike Espy was acquitted on all counts related to alleged acceptance of gifts and attempts to deceive investigators. Several individuals pleaded guilty or were found guilty in connection with the investigation. Several individuals, including James H. Lake, Brook K. Mitchell, Sr., John Hemmingson, Alverez Ferrouillet, Jack L. Williams, and Richard Douglas, were pardoned by President Clinton on January 20, 2001. Independent Counsel Smaltz's final report was filed on January 30, 2001, and published by the court on October 25, 2001. The cost of the investigations by Independent Counsel Smaltz through September 30, 2005, totaled $25,157,010. David M. Barrett was appointed on May 24, 1995, to investigate allegations against HUD Secretary Henry G. Cisneros. Former Secretary Cisneros was indicted on December 11, 1997, along with Linda (Medlar) Jones and two former aides. Former Secretary Cisneros and Linda Jones, along with others, were indicted on various charges including fraud and money laundering. Cisneros pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor charge and was fined. President Clinton pardoned Cisneros and Jones in 2001. The Special Division of the Court of Appeals decided not to terminate the office of Independent Counsel Barrett in 2001. The final report was filed in 2004, with the investigation costing $24,438,915. Daniel S. Pearson was appointed as independent counsel in 1995 to investigate financial dealings of Secretary of Commerce Ronald H. Brown, with the investigation ending upon Brown's death in 1996. The cost of this investigation was $3,861,710. Curtis E. von Kann was appointed in 1996. Curtis E. von Kann was appointed in 1996 to investigate conflict of interest law violations by Eli Segal. No indictments were returned, and the investigation cost $628,156. Ralph I. Lancaster was appointed in 1998 to investigate unlawful solicitation of campaign contributions by Secretary of Labor, Alexis Herman. The only indictment in the investigation was of a Singapore businessman, Abdul Rahman, for illegal campaign contributions. The final report was submitted in April 2000, with expenditures related to the investigation totaling $6,027,860.
